docs.lead_paragraph: A supposed boom in startup companies may just be acts of desperation by workers who’ve lost their jobs.
docs.snippet: A supposed boom in startup companies may just be acts of desperation by workers who’ve lost their jobs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Berkeley, Calif. LAST year was a fabulous one for entrepreneurs, at least according to the Kauffman Index of Entrepreneurial Activity released last month by the Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation. ''Rather than making history for its deep recession and record unemployment,'' the foundation reported, ''2009 might instead be remembered as the year business startups reached their highest level in 14 years -- even exceeding the number of startups during the peak 1999-2000 technology boom.''
docs.abstract: Former Labor Sec Robert B Reich Op-Ed article holds that reason 2009 saw 14-year high for small business startups was because of unemployment, with millions of Americans booted off company payrolls and left with no choice but to sell themselves as self-employed entrepreneurs; cautions that thinking of them as innovative owners of startups misses one of most significant changes in American work force in decades; calls on Congress to push bills that would make more credit available to startups; urges consideration of 'earnings insurance,' and tax credits that would take place of lost 401(k) corporate matches; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Berkeley, Calif.     LAST year was a fabulous one for entrepreneurs, at least according to the Kauffman Index of Entrepreneurial Activity released last month by the Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation. ''Rather than making history for its deep recession...

docs.lead_paragraph: RAND--Dr. Anna T.,who died peacefully on May 30, 2010 at the age of 96, is mourned by her family and the many people she touched. Anna led an extraordinary life. In addition to her private practice, she served as a staff physician for numerous embassies in the 1940's and 1950's, Director of Planned Parenthood in Washington, D.C. during the 1940's and 1950's, Board Member of Planned Parenthood in New York from the 1950's to 1970's, professor and Director of Family Planning Activities at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Jacobi and Lincoln Hospitals in the 1960's and 1970's. As the Chairperson of the Washington, D.C. Chapter of Physicians Forum in the 1940's and 1950's, she was a passionate advocate of women's reproductive health, abortion rights, National Health Insurance and the delivery of adequate health care to all communities. Anna was committed to, and worked tirelessly for social justice and was a lifelong supporter of countless progressive causes. She is survived by and will be greatly missed by her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren and their families, Steven and Marlyse, Naomi and David, Deborah, Sascha, and Kalpana, Travis, Cody, Krish and Anand, by her brother Sam and sisters-in-law Adele and Jeanne, and by her nephews, niece and numerous cousins, all of whom loved her deeply. The love of her life, her wonderful husband Harry I. Rand, died in 2005. A memorial in her honor will be held on Saturday, June 12 at 3pm at her apartment, 320 West 86 Street, Manhattan.

docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline.main: Tuesday Reading: The Legal Risk of Online Complaining

docs.abstract: How some businesses are battling consumers' online complaints in court, why it still may not be easier to insure your young adult and other consumer-focused items from Tuesday's Times.

headline.print_headline: Seeking an Objective Test for Attention Disorder

docs.snippet: Finding objective evidence, or a biological marker, for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder could cut the guesswork in diagnoses.

docs.lead_paragraph: Alexander Carno passes too much time staring out the window of the tidy bedroom he shares with his grandfather, relying on binoculars to take him down 19 flights to the Harlem street below. Sometimes, being a 17-year-old boy, he notices a girl, or watches his old friends, hanging out and laughing. Sometimes, he stares at the corner where he was shot last December, remembering the moment when he realized, as bullet met bone, that his legs no longer did as they were told. ''I tried to run,'' he said recently. ''But nothing's faster than a bullet.'' With dizzying speed, the pace of his life slowed to a crawl. It now takes patience no teenager has to move to the door with a walker, to wait for a visit from a friend, to wait for someone to call someone who could arrange for the right paperwork.

headline.main: An Accidental Health Care Advocate, Throwing a Lifeline to a Teenager in Need

docs.abstract: Susan Dominus Big City column on relationship between Alexander Carno, Harlem teenager recovering from gunshot wound, and Jenny Goldstock Wright, woman who met Carno in recovery room of Burke Rehabilitation Hospital in Westchester; Goldstock Wright has become friend to and health care advocate for Carno; photos (M)
